Title.evidence: Conclusion: We found no clinically important differences (and few differences overall) between short and standard-length THA stems 5 years after surgery in a randomized trial.

Trial_Design.evidence: Our study was powered at 80% to detect a 10% difference in the proportion of patients reporting thigh pain at the level of 0.05.

Participants.evidence: To be eligible, patients needed to be at least 20 years of age, have not undergone previous history of hip surgery, and have no metabolic bone disease.

Intervention.evidence: A total of 100 patients were randomized to receive THA either with a short stem (n = 56) or with a standard-length stem (n = 44).

Objective.evidence: Questions/purposes: Is there a difference between short- and standard-length stems in terms of: (1) the frequency or severity of thigh pain, (2) modified Harris hip scores, (3) implant loosening, or (4) bone mineral density as measured by dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry?

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary endpoint of our study was the incidence of thigh pain during 5-year follow-up.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: A total of 100 patients were randomized to receive THA either with a short stem (n = 56) or with a standard-length stem (n = 44).

Blinding.evidence: The modified Harris hip score was calculated by research assistants who were blinded to the treatment groups.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 100 patients were randomized to receive THA either with a short stem (n = 56) or with a standard-length stem (n = 44).

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 73% (41 of 56) and 77% (34 of 44) of those groups, respectively, were accounted for at a minimum of 5 years and were analyzed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: We found no difference between the groups in the proportion of patients with thigh pain; 16% (9 of 56) of patients in the short-stem group and 14% (6 of 44) of patients in the standard-stem group experienced thigh pain during the follow-up period (p = 0.79).
